text: Not a resource, just my thoughts, and this makes me think of Support/Care content goals. My first thought is some type of NPS score where you ask for feedback on how helpful a user found the information (passively, with options at the bottom/side of the page), if the content solved challenges: Y/N, etc. Via google analytics you could also track video plays, PDF downloads, and % scroll depth on articles to measure engagement metrics. But aiming for a mix of active engagement (like downloads/video plays) and sentiment (rating: 1-10, solved it: Y/N, liked it: smile vs frown) could give you a good mix. Allowing input boxes based on people's feedback to gather more info is helpful when acting on sentiment data, but at a minimum lots of "frowns" or "no's" would highlight content not doing it's job in the user's mind. Hope that's helpful!

text:
We tried a team editing rotation earlier this year (3 people on the team). Everyone actually really enjoyed it and it had benefits outside of editing—encouraging collaboration and discussion while remote, etc. This could be good from a knowledge-sharing perspective, for example informing your content with more product perspective, etc. We also all did the ACES editing certificate course as a group with our SEO team which gave us room to talk about best practices, editing expectations, etc. and we created an editing checklist for the writer and editor to use in every review.

I did find that it was effective for structural issues, flow, things that just “weren’t quite working” and everyone actually enjoyed it a lot. However, adding editing meant that the two team members who produce the most content had less time for creation, which wasn’t ok from a prioritization standpoint. Right now we’re back to me editing most work, but hoping to change in the new year.

elements.text:

I did find that it was effective for structural issues, flow, things that just “weren’t quite working” and everyone actually enjoyed it a lot. However, adding editing meant that the two team members who produce the most content had less time for creation, which wasn’t ok from a prioritization standpoint. Right now we’re back to me editing most work, but hoping to change in the new year.

text: Have any of you dealt with increasingly tight restrictions or evaluation of your content from your own legal dept? Particularly after going public?

elements.text: Have any of you dealt with increasingly tight restrictions or evaluation of your content from your own legal dept? Particularly after going public?

text: Not after going public, but I write for an SEC-regulated investment advisor, so…yes lol. I find that our compliance team goes through more conservative phases, especially when we introduce new things, and gradually becomes more comfortable over time. I also find that often, I can probe a little into WHY they made a certain edit to get to the heart of the actual compliance concern, which helps me write around it in a way we are all more comfortable with.

elements.text: Not after going public, but I write for an SEC-regulated investment advisor, so…yes lol. I find that our compliance team goes through more conservative phases, especially when we introduce new things, and gradually becomes more comfortable over time. I also find that often, I can probe a little into WHY they made a certain edit to get to the heart of the actual compliance concern, which helps me write around it in a way we are all more comfortable with.

text: Oh yes. We've been public since 2014, but our legal department has changed leadership a handful of times and goes through waves of marketing scrutiny, usually resulting in more ®s than I'd like.

elements.text: Oh yes. We've been public since 2014, but our legal department has changed leadership a handful of times and goes through waves of marketing scrutiny, usually resulting in more ®s than I'd like.

text: Interesting. Do either of you have anything like a “claims review” process? We’re having to submit each “legal claim” - the definition of which is very murky but is basically any fact from “XX% of blah did thing” to “Observation on industry based on knowledge.” It’s like tripled our production times, among other negatives. <@UVCDN5SQZ> <@U01GGQMG6HW>

attachments.title: Zero to Marketing
attachments.text: Every two weeks I pick a new online business and write a 5-minute read case study with actionable tips on how I'd grow it.

text:
Every team I've worked with in regulated markets (medical/pharam/finance/insurance) as well as copyright markets like stock photography has had to deal with legal reviews. And it's always the longest production or review step because the legal team pushes it to the very bottom of their list.

The best way I've seen to deal with it is getting the legal team to give you a best practices/checklist of what you can/can't say that you can train writers on - and once they know you stick to it, getting them to commit to a shorter turnaround time on reviews tends to be a bit easier. Some teams are definitely better than others, of course.

elements.text:

Some teams are definitely better than others, of course.

text: <@U016AG4A2G2> We keep a google sheet called Common Claims and their Sources. If you can put the ones you’re using all the time in one place and get sign-off on THAT, they may be comfortable with you using them for the uses as approved without having them check each one.

elements.text: We keep a google sheet called Common Claims and their Sources. If you can put the ones you’re using all the time in one place and get sign-off on THAT, they may be comfortable with you using them for the uses as approved without having them check each one.

text: (this also makes writing/sourcing much easier lol)

elements.text: (this also makes writing/sourcing much easier lol)

text: Ultimately, though, compliance review is just a step that we’ve had to bake into our process. Our team has asked for a 48 hour SLA, which we can sometimes accommodate and sometimes need to ask for rushes. The most important thing is their commitment to timely review if they are going to require it. If it’s not happening, your leadership team might need to step in and make it clear that turnaround times are a priority.

elements.text: Ultimately, though, compliance review is just a step that we’ve had to bake into our process. Our team has asked for a 48 hour SLA, which we can sometimes accommodate and sometimes need to ask for rushes. The most important thing is their commitment to timely review if they are going to require it. If it’s not happening, your leadership team might need to step in and make it clear that turnaround times are a priority.

text: <@U016AG4A2G2> Similar to Deedi, it's baked right into our content approval process. Would strongly recommend an open dialogue "hey, how do we improve this process?" meeting, as that's worked for my team. (Bonus points for bringing along a marketing exec or sales person who gets it to vouch for the importance of swift content delivery.) Legal doesn't want to be the bad guy, so hear them out and find a happy medium. It's a process.

elements.text: Similar to Deedi, it's baked right into our content approval process. Would strongly recommend an open dialogue "hey, how do we improve this process?" meeting, as that's worked for my team. (Bonus points for bringing along a marketing exec or sales person who gets it to vouch for the importance of swift content delivery.) Legal doesn't want to be the bad guy, so hear them out and find a happy medium. It's a process.

text: Yeah, we have it baked into the process now, and we are using a master claims sheet, but we would kill for a 48 hour turnaround! The issue is being escalated way above my paygrade, fortunately, but I was curious how our process compares in its stringency. Currently we’re having a difficult time making industry observations/producing thought leadership because they want so much backup around everything we say.

text:
It's definitely common. Two ideas come to mind:

1. Editorial guidelines and a pre-publish checklist that illustrates standards for integrity. 
2. Track the requested changes and evaluate the results with the legal team on a quarterly basis. 
These two things will demonstrate your commitment to their concerns. And the second idea in particular quantifies the effectiveness of the first and the efficiency of the process.

elements.text: It's definitely common. Two ideas come to mind:
Editorial guidelines and a pre-publish checklist that illustrates standards for integrity.
Track the requested changes and evaluate the results with the legal team on a quarterly basis.
These two things will demonstrate your commitment to their concerns. And the second idea in particular quantifies the effectiveness of the first and the efficiency of the process.

text: Le sigh! I know!! Im trying to make the case that discovery on a platform like Instagram is is in tags and dynamic searching that brings content based on who you follow and that multiple accounts cant really do that for you. The client used the example of Complex and some media entities that have multiple sub-accounts...but they also have 7 M followers.

text: Yeah, media and finance are two different instagram beasts. And Instagram is for a very particular demo anyway -- there's so many options for platforms for all four of those personas! Pinterest for the single parent managing it all... facebook for the retiree getting their budget in order...I know those are stereotypes but there are different platforms for a reason.
